messageBody:
Jim Cakalic wrote:

> 3. Determine whether Extract Class should be used to split the
> responsibilities of the class into two or more abstractions. If so,
> refactor and write unit tests for the public methods of the new
> classes. Return to step 1.
>

I don't see this as a solution. If the method wasn't public before, it
shouldn't be public now just because it moved to a different class. If
the only reason it becomes public is because it moved to a different
class, it would be better off as the original private method inside the
one class. Public API should be kept to a minimum, especially if you
expect anybody to use your API. If the API is purely for your app's own
internal use, then this constraint can be relaxed a little, but you
should still strive for the minimum exposure of class internals. This is
one of the first principles of object oriented design, and test driven
development doesn't really change it to any significant extent.
